column2: Where are the glomeruli and what do they do?Renal cortex. Filter blood from the afferent arterioles.
column3: Where are the glomeruli and what do they do?

column2:
Histological structure of normal glomerulus

Urinary pole where urine flows out is on far side.
Vascular pole where blood comes and leaves is on the close side (afferent and efferent)

1) Surrounds glomerulus
2) Line Bowman's space
3) Where urine is filtered into
4) Coat the glomerular "tuft"
5) Little thin loops within the tuft
6) Basement membrane of capillaries
7) Afferent arteriole cells
8) Branched structure in the middle of the glomerular tuft, means "middle vessels", capillaries wind themselves around the mesangium

EM of Glomerulus; name the parts

1) Makes foot processes
2) Provides basement membrane for blood to be filtered across
3) Divides inner portion of capillary loop from urinary space
4) Where the blood input comes from
5) Matrix for capillaries to wind around
6) From the visceral epithelial cells, they line outer part of capillary loop
7) The space between foot processes and endothelial fenestrations
8) The blood side of the filter



Don't need to distinguish the layers of the lamina
column3: EM of Glomerulus; name the parts

column2: Immune Mediated glomerular disease types

Define diffuse, focal, global, and segmental disease

1) Most or all glomeruli are involved

2) Some glomeruli involved

3) Entire glomerulus

4) Part of glomerulus
column3: Define diffuse, focal, global, and segmental disease

column2:
3 main presentations of Glomerular Disease

RPGN
Acute Nephritic Syndrome

RPGN clinical signs and symptoms


Signs and symptoms of severe nephritic syndrome

Nephrotic Syndrome

Due to altered foot processes of visceral epithelium

Causes of nephrotic syndrome
Mostly:

- Minimal change disease in children


- Focal segmental glomerulonephritis and 
- Membranous glomerulopathy in adults

Can also be caused by systemic diseases

Nephritic and Nephrotic damage basement membrane in different ways...

Nephrotic- foot process abnormality

Nephritic- inflammation and thrombosis of endothelium
column3: Nephritic and Nephrotic damage basement membrane in different ways...

column2:
Possible locations of immune complex deposition in the glomerulus

The ones that matter to us:

1) Epithelial = nephrotic

3) Endothelial = nephritic

4) Mesangium = both

column2:
Type III RPGN

Most common

No immunofluorescence picture  

pANCA = myeloperoxidase

cANCA = proteinase 3

p and c ANCA

pANCA = perinuclear = myeloperoxidase

cANCA = cytoplasmic = proteinase 3
A

Membranous Nephropathy
Common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults

Subepithelial immune complex deposition

Phospholipase A2 receptor resides in foot process

Complement mediated

Thick, saw-toothed, spiked glomerular basement membrane

Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis
Most common cause is abnormal immune reaction to hepatitis C infection

Most glomeruli involved (diffuse)

Double basement membranes


 



dark material in subendothelial location

IgA NephropathyMost common primary glomerulonephritis in the world

Big in Asia and Australia 

Accumulation of IgA in mesangium
